Finding aid for
Samuel Taubman papers, 1932-2000

Finding aid created by
Polly Reynolds, January 2007

did.abstract: Samuel Taubman was a 1940 University of Michigan graduate of aeronautical engineering. He served as a ground school instructor for the Civil Aeronautics Administration Aviation Ground School, worked as an engineer for Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, and later owned the National Shower Manufacturing Company in Detroit and a plant in Florida. He applied his knowledge of aircraft construction, inventing civilian products using aircraft aluminum, most notably for shower door design and manufacture. His papers include his engineering work at the University of Michigan and Lockheed, his teaching materials from Aviation Ground School, patents, designs, and photographs of his shower door designs as well as journals and drawings.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers were donated by Lola Taubman (donor no. 9779) in September 2006.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Samuel Taubman papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Samuel Taubman was born in Davenport, Iowa on August 17, 1915. He graduated from Pontiac High School in Pontiac, Michigan in 1933 and attended Pontiac Junior College. He earned his Bachelor of Science degree in 1940 in aeronautical engineering at the University of Michigan. He served as a ground school instructor for the Civil Aeronautics Administration Aviation Ground School at the University of California.

He worked as an engineer at Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the 1940s, where he designed testing equipment and methodology and also designed aircraft components. Taubman also enrolled in naval training schools in Dearborn, Michigan and Chicago, Illinois. While working for Lockheed, he enlisted in the Navy serving on the USS Randolph.

Later in his life, Taubman applied his knowledge of aircraft construction, inventing civilian products using aircraft aluminum, most notably shower door design and manufacture. In the 1950s, he founded the National Shower Manufacturing Company in Detroit and developed more than a dozen patents for his designs.

In 1980, Taubman moved his factory to Sanford, Florida, as it was no longer economically feasible to meet the new EPA pollution control requirements at the Detroit plant. He joined with a man named John Wall expanding his product line, developing products such as roll down shutters to protect windows from hurricanes, archery arrows, parts for medical devices, and window frames. National Shower continued in existence as a division, but was gradually phased out of active production in favor of other pursuits at the new facility.

In 1993, Taubman sold his interest in the factory, but remained as a consulting engineer on numerous projects including the design of an electrostatic paint line. The paint line had a long loop of chain used as a parts conveyor. Taubman calculated that the metal chain would become slack as temperatures rose from the Florida sun. He therefore added a large pulley wheel at one end of the line with hydraulic pistons which would gradually extend to take up slack in the chain. From 1993 to 2004, he also designed the interiors of Gulfstream jets built for his brother, A. Alfred Taubman. He died on December 15, 2004.

scopecontent.p: Samuel Taubman's papers include his engineering work at UM and Lockheed, his teaching materials from Aviation Ground School, patents, designs, and photographs of his shower door designs as well as journals and drawings.

The papers have been divided into six series according to the chronology of Taubman's life and work: Pontiac High School, University of Michigan, Aeronautics Administration Aviation Ground School (University of California), Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, Naval Training Schools, and National Shower Manufacturing Company and Later Work.

odd.p: See related materials in Drawings series

did.unittitle: University of California, Civil Aeronautics Administration, Aviation Ground School 1939-1941

scopecontent.p: The Aeronautics Administration Aviation Ground School (University of California) series (1939-1941, 0.25 linear feet) contains teaching material such as lecture notes and exams while serving as a ground school instructor.

did.unittitle: Progress report on the Civil Aeronautics Authority's Pilot Training Program at the University of Michigan February 9, 1940

scopecontent.p: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation series (1940-1945, 1 linear foot) includes his work at Lockheed including correspondence, patents, as well several reports from aircraft equipment tests.

did.unittitle: Operation-damage tests of proposed model-49 flap tracks undated
Operation-damage tests of proposed model-49 flap-extending cables January 7, 1943
Test of control-cable tension governor December 23, 1942
Tests of ducted-skin compression panels January 24, 1944
Tests of floor-support structure in airplane no. 1962 of model-49 series undated
Tests and developments of proposed model-89 flap-system rollers and tracks 1945
Model-349 cargo floor panel tests February 2, 1943
Pressure tests of proposed model-349 cabin windows undated
Static tests of proposed model-349 floor structure November 30, 1942
Preliminary design and stress analysis of main rings-front stabilizer bulkhead-ring at station 150 September 16, 1940
An investigation of the crushing loads imposed on using ribs by wing flexure April 2, 1941
Tests to determine the characteristics of double-skin type of wing construction 1941
The construction and operation of the Lockheed electrical system for measuring strains November 7, 1941
National Shower Manufacturing Company and Later Work 1935-2000

scopecontent.p: The National Shower Manufacturing Company and Later Work series (3 linear feet, 1 oversize box, 11 tubes of drawings, and 1 oversize model, 1935-2000) includes his work at the National Shower Manufacturing Company, including patent and trademark applications, photographs of shower door and sandblasting designs, drawings, and showroom samples and models. Taubman's later work as a consulting engineer to his Florida factory can also be found in this series including his drawings of the electrostatic paint line as well as detailed notes of his daily activities (1992-2000) as tracked in his daily planners.
